awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium: Microbiology on a Programmable Biochip: An Integrated Hardware/Software Digital Microfluidics Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to develop miniaturized, low-cost, and smart microfluidic biochips that can perform "epigenetics in a drop". Such a platform will revolutionize data acquisition for molecular biology studies. The knowledge gained from applying molecular biology protocols to microfluidic biochips will facilitate the understanding of diseases such as cancer, and knowledge about epigenetic modifications in cells from inheritance will broaden the understanding of disease development. The results from this research will also be applicable to quantitative analysis protocols such as gene expression analysis. This project will foster multi-disciplinary education for engineering students and it has the potential to pave the way for new high-tech companies. 

This research has been structured as an interdisciplinary collaboration between investigators with complementary expertise in design automation and system architecture for microfluidics, digital microfluidics technology, and molecular biology. It will lead to an integrated 5-layer system architecture for the seamless on-chip execution of complex biochemical protocols. Breakthroughs in design automation will enable real-time decision-making based on prescribed decision criteria; such a design will allow a diverse collection of protocol paths to be traversed. Research objectives include system design and optimization methods to support quantitative analysis protocols, demonstration of biomolecular protocols on microfluidic biochips, and evaluation of design automation solutions using test cases extracted from benchtop implementation of biomolecular protocols.

por.por_cntn:
This project was aimed at advancing miniaturized, low-cost, and smart microfluidic biochips that can perform "epigenetics in a drop". The research was structured as an interdisciplinary collaboration between investigators with complementary expertise in design automation and system architecture for microfluidics, digital microfluidics technology, and molecular biology. This work has led to an integrated multi-layer system architecture for the seamless on-chip execution of complex biochemical protocols. Breakthroughs in design automation have enabled real-time decision-making based on decision criteria (sensor feedback). Specific outcomes include system design and optimization methods to support quantitative analysis protocols, demonstration of biomolecular protocols on microfluidic biochips, and evaluation of design automation solutions using test cases extracted from benchtop implementation of biomolecular protocols. 

In particular, the investigators developed microfluidic biochip optimization methods for single cell analysis applications. This work led to a Best Paper Award at the IEEE/ACM DATE conference in 2017. Another breakthrough that emerged is the connection between digital microfluidics and machine learning. Sensor feedback (image data from a camera observing droplet movement) was fed to a reinforcement learning framework that can provide adaptive droplet routing solutions. In this way, electrode degradation can be avoided and droplet pathways can be designed dynamically. This work was published in the ICML conference two years in a row (2020, 2021) and experimental demonstration made using fabricated devices. Successful collaborations were established with researchers in Germany and Taiwan.

The knowledge gained from this project on applying molecular biology protocols to microfluidic biochips will facilitate the understanding of diseases such as cancer, and knowledge about epigenetic modifications in cells from inheritance will broaden the understanding of disease development. This project has provided multi-disciplinary education to multiple PhD students in engineering. These students are now well-placed in industry and one of these students is pursuing academic job opportunities after a valuable postdoc experience.
